title: A Legible Medieval typeface that subtly hints at being Medieval?
content:
Hello,

I am looking for a Medieval typeface that I can use for a poster that subtly hints at being Medieval and not one that is over flamboyant and difficult to read.

Any suggestions would be much appreciated!

Free typefaces would be best but please suggest all - free is just a bonus.

MrKerner
author: MrKerner

comments.content:
What about a rotunda?

[http://www.myfonts.com/search/rotunda/fonts/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150417085501/http:/www.myfonts.com/search/rotunda/fonts/ "http://www.myfonts.com/search/rotunda/fonts/")

My Espinosa Nova Rotunda:

[http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/estudio-ch/espinosa-nova/rotunda-bold-alt/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150417085501/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/estudio-ch/espinosa-nova/rotunda-bold-alt/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/estudio-ch/espinosa-nova/rotunda-bold-alt/")

How subtle a hint are you looking for? You may be thinking of something like [Cloister Lightface](http://web.archive.org/web/20150417085501/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/ef/cloister-old-style-b/) (another version [here](http://web.archive.org/web/20150417085501/http:/www.p22.com/lanston/cloister.html)) (and [still another](http://web.archive.org/web/20150417085501/http:/typophile.com/wiki/https%3A/%252Fwww.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/urw/urw_cloister_old_style_ot/)) or (less subtle) [Jenson Oldstyle](http://web.archive.org/web/20150417085501/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/woodentypefonts/jensen-old-style/) instead of a rotunda, although rotundas are highly legible.

Rotunda is good, but maybe still a bit too medieval.

I guess I am looking for Medieval with a bit of modern too.

Cloister is quite nice - Medieval. I do like the 'e' and the 'k'.

Jenson could be another possibility.

A typeface with a bit more Medieval to it would be great. Something in between Rutunda and Cloister.

Hmm. I'm going to point you at Manfred Klein's site:

[http://manfred-klein.ina-mar.com/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150417085501/http:/manfred-klein.ina-mar.com/)  
 [http://moorstation.org/typoasis/designers/klein/index.htm](http://web.archive.org/web/20150417085501/http:/moorstation.org/typoasis/designers/klein/index.htm)

Or you might want something like Kingthings Petrock or Perry Gothic.

Ah, _here's_ the type designer I was really thinking of:

[http://moorstation.org/typoasis/designers/steffmann/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150417085501/http:/moorstation.org/typoasis/designers/steffmann/)

He specializes in typefaces that might be of interest, for example there is this rotunda:

[http://moorstation.org/typoasis/designers/steffmann/samples/t/typo\_rotunda.htm](http://web.archive.org/web/20150417085501/http:/moorstation.org/typoasis/designers/steffmann/samples/t/typo_rotunda.htm)

And from Typodermic Fonts, there's Goodfish and Vinque.
How about the ["country specific" versions of Andron](http://web.archive.org/web/20150417085501/http:/www.signographie.de/cms/front_content.php?idart=306)?
There are various understated Carolingian faces that might fit. [Alcuin](http://web.archive.org/web/20150417085501/http:/www.myfonts.com/search/alcuin/fonts/), for example.
